content.title: Dimensional Analysis Method for Planck Units
content.summary: Dimensional analysis is a systematic technique for deriving any Planck unit from fundamental constants. By matching the dimensions of a physical quantity to combinations of fundamental constants, one uniquely determines the Planck scale for that quantity.

core_principle.statement: Any physical quantity X with dimensions [M^a L^b T^c] can be expressed as a unique combination of fundamental constants c, ℏ, and G.

method_steps.title: Express the target quantity in base dimensions
method_steps.description: Write the physical quantity in terms of [M, L, T]
method_steps.example: For length: [X] = [L], for energy: [X] = [M L² T⁻²]

method_steps.title: Set up the dimensional equation
method_steps.formula: [M^a L^b T^c] = [L T⁻¹]^α × [M L² T⁻¹]^β × [M⁻¹ L³ T⁻²]^γ

method_steps.title: Solve the system for α, β, γ
method_steps.note: Three equations, three unknowns → unique solution

content.key_insight: The method works because c, ℏ, G form a complete basis for mechanical dimensions [M, L, T]. Adding k_B extends to temperature [K], and adding e or ε₀ extends to electromagnetic units.
advantages: No physics knowledge required beyond dimensions
Gives exact algebraic relationships, not estimates
Reveals natural scales inherent in fundamental constants
Self-consistent: results automatically have correct dimensions
limitations: Gives only the Planck scale, not numerical factors
Requires choosing which constants to use
